Hi Colin,
   Just a couple of comments:

> I have been thinking about wheth=
er to use CVS or SVN. 

Having used and administered both CVS & SVN for yea=
rs, SVN definitely
wins out in my experience on many different points. A po=
pular quick
start guide:
http://haacked.com/archive/2006/02/22/QuickstartGu=
idetoSubversiononSourceForge.aspx
for SVN on sourceforge (http://sourceforg=
e.net/docs/E09).

>I really like
> the support for these repositories in Ec=
lipse (www.eclipse.org), and
> even if you make it very restricted access i=
t can still be useful to
> see detailed revision histories for files. It's =
another level of
> transparency (after providing the source code) that can =
aid in using
> the codebase and confirming/finding bugs.
> ...
> > The othe=
r aspect I'm fuzzy on is CVS/SVN support in MS Visual Studio

http://ankhsv=
n.tigris.org/ "AnkhSVN: A Subversion addin for Microsoft
Visual Studio .NET=
". I use it extensively, works beautifully (much
better than the inbuilt Vi=
sual Source Safe) although its still handy
to have tortoisesvn installed as=
 well for the off rare chore.

There is a .NET plugin for Eclipse floating =
around but have never used
it myself.

--
Keith
